This explains the words of the aforementioned Midrash where Yehudah said, "If I come for war, if I come for appeasement, if I come for prayer." This is based on what the holy Yismach Moshe wrote (in Parshat Vayeshev) in the name of the holy Kedushat Levi, that in the days of the Chashmonaim, the miracle was not complete because it came through war. The way of the Torah is that those below should not take any physical action, but rather [rely] only on prayer and supplication before the Holy One, Blessed be He.

However, there are times when Heaven agreed to war, such as in the days of the Chashmonaim, the Kohanim Gedolim who fought according to Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration), and King David who fought his wars through the counsel of the Urim v'Tumim and Ruach HaKodesh. There were other kings who received Heaven's consent for war. There were also times when Heaven did not agree to fight against the nations, and they needed to appease them with gifts and bribe them with money, combined with the power of prayer, and in this way they were saved from them. In the future, the nations of the world will return all these gifts, as mentioned above.

In our times, these being Ikveta d'Meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), we have no permission to wage war against them, and we have no counsel or remedy except to pray to Hashem, and this is our only hope. Therefore, Yehudah mentioned all these three aspects, as he was king over the tribes, and Melech HaMashiach (King Messiah) will come from Yehudah. Thus, he enumerated all these times and aspects that Israel will experience until the coming of Mashiach.

This is what is meant by "if for war" - meaning if Heaven agrees to war and it is the Supreme Will, then I come to fight, alluding to David who comes from Yehudah, and also alluding to other kings who fought by Hashem's command, as Yehudah is the head of kingship. He also alluded to them by saying "I come." Similarly, "if for appeasement I come," and "if for prayer" - when it is the Supreme Will that salvation should come through prayer alone, then I come with the power of prayer.

This refers to Melech HaMashiach who comes from Yehudah, that Mashiach Tzidkeinu will come without physical action and without war. In truth, the power and merit of prayer must be combined with both war and appeasement. When it says "if for prayer," it means prayer alone, excluding war, and through the power of prayer alone Mashiach Tzidkeinu will come.

Unfortunately, in our days, hearts have become blocked, and we lack the ability to pour out speech and supplications with a complete heart. However, the power of prayer has already been prepared by the holy Avot and the Shevatim (tribes), as written in the holy Zohar (Parshat Toldot), that through the prayers of the tzaddikim, holiness increases and is added to all who need it, especially regarding the final exile and the future redemption, which they saw through their holy spirit and prayed for. The power and merit of their prayers are preserved for the time of grace when the appointed time comes, and surely it will help and assist that our prayers too will be accepted, Amen, so may it be His will.

Indeed, their holy words remain eternal for all generations, as they paved the way and opened a wellspring of salvation for their children after them. As the holy Yitav Lev wrote (in Parshat Toldot) regarding what is found in the holy Zohar: "Isaac waited twenty years with his wife who did not bear children until he prayed his prayer, because the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of tzaddikim (righteous ones). Why? Because through the prayers of tzaddikim, holy abundance increases and is added for all who need it."

The holy Yitav Lev wrote that this is comparable to a blocked pipe - if someone comes and opens it and cleans it out, it then remains open for all. Similarly, through the prayers of tzaddikim, the channels of salvation and kindness are opened, and whoever needs the waters of salvation can draw joyfully from that pipe, as it is written, "And you shall draw water with joy from the wellsprings of salvation." The commentators explained that the salvation of tzaddikim is like a flowing spring bringing salvation immediately and for generations, and therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, desires their prayers, for through their prayers the pipe and spring are opened for all who need that thing.

This explains the words of the Midrash: "Deep waters are counsel in the heart of man..." - A parable of a deep well full of cold water, and its waters were cold and good, but no creature could drink from it. Someone came and tied rope to rope, etc., and drew from it and drank. Then everyone began drawing and drinking from it. Similarly, Judah did not cease responding to Joseph, etc.

The holy tribes did not need these actions for themselves, as they had the power of their holiness to bring about salvation for themselves regardless. But they did all this so that there would be a wellspring of salvation flowing for generations, and there is relevance in their holy words for all generations, each generation according to its situation and circumstances. Therefore their words showed different aspects, so that the flowing spring of salvation would continue for generations for whoever needs it. Thus Judah kept responding to Joseph point by point until he understood his heart, and all draw and drink from them for all generations.

Initially, they said "G-d has found the sin of your servants; behold, we are servants to my master, etc." Rashi explains: "We know we did not transgress, but this has come upon us from the Almighty - here a creditor has found [an opportunity] to collect his debt."

The Radak explains that David was not punished for this bloodshed, as his intention was to eliminate the wicked who would breach [the security of] Israel, etc. However, since he was involved in extensive bloodshed, he was prevented from building the Beis HaMikdash (Holy Temple), which represents peace and atonement for sin. This is similar to the prohibition against using iron on the altar and in the Beis HaMikdash, as iron is used to make weapons of killing and should not be used to make instruments of peace.

However, in the Pesikta d'Rav Kahana (in the section about Chanukah), it states: "A psalm for the dedication of the House, by David." Come and see that Solomon built the House, yet it was called by David's name. This is because David was worthy to build it, but due to one matter he did not build it. Although he intended to build it, Nathan the Prophet came and told him, "You shall not build the House, because you have shed much blood on the earth." When David heard this, he became afraid and said, "I have been disqualified from building the Beis HaMikdash." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to David, "Do not fear. By your life, these [bloodsheds] are before Me like [the blood of] a deer or a hart... All the blood you shed was before Me like sacrifices, as it is written 'because you have shed much blood on the earth before Me.'"

David asked, "If so, why can't I build it?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "Because if you build it, it will stand permanently and never be destroyed." David said, "But that would be good!" The Holy One, Blessed be He, responded, "It is revealed and known before Me that they [Israel] will sin in the future, and I will vent My wrath upon it [the Temple] and destroy it, and [thereby] Israel will be saved."

This seems to require explanation, as there appears to be a contradiction between the beginning and end. It starts by saying David couldn't build the Temple because he shed much blood, but concludes that it was because of David's great spiritual level that enemies would not have power over his handiwork. Similar to what I explained regarding the verse where Yaakov Avinu (our father Jacob) said to Lavan, "With whomever you find your gods, he shall not live," and from that curse Rachel died on the way. At first glance, how could it be that Yaakov Avinu uttered a curse, and how did he not worry that perhaps his wives or children had taken the terafim (idols), as was indeed the case that Rachel had taken them?

I explained that Yaakov Avinu was precise in his language to avoid uttering a curse, Heaven forbid. Therefore, he didn't say "whoever has your gods in their possession shall not live," rather he said "with whomever you find your gods," and Yaakov Avinu knew that Lavan wouldn't find them. I've explained this in various other ways as well (see our words on Parshat Vayetzei).

However, since to the eye and according to the simple meaning of his words, it appeared as if he was cursing whoever had the avodah zarah (idolatry) in their possession, therefore the curse found a place to take effect and Rachel died on the way. This is similar to what our Sages said that a wise man's curse, even if conditional, comes to pass, because his speech makes an impression even if he didn't intend it.

Similarly in our matter, since Yehudah's words appeared outwardly as a curse, his bones were consequently scattered, because a wise man's curse, even if conditional, makes an impression. Following our approach, this resolves the question of the Ra'avad and other commentators of why Yehudah didn't annul his nidui (ban). It is known that the way of tzaddikim (righteous ones) is to always attribute deficiency to themselves, and they suspect themselves of not yet having reached perfection. Therefore, according to Yehudah's knowledge and understanding, he didn't need annulment, because he knew through ruach hakodesh (Divine inspiration) at the time of the nidui that he would be able to fulfill his condition, and he wasn't concerned about the principle that a wise man's curse comes to pass even if conditional, because he didn't consider himself to be on such a level that his words would make an impression in every case.

One can suggest another praiseworthy reason why someone whose intention and thoughts are proper is permitted to make a vow even if they don't have the means to give immediately. For one whose mind is properly focused participates in the pain of the needy person. Consequently, their heart won't feel bad about giving; on the contrary, their heart will ache more for the trouble of their fellow who needs to receive their donation. And since they share in the pain of the recipient, it is considered a time of distress, and the Tur and Shulchan Aruch ruled in Hilchos Nedarim (203:7) that during a time of distress it is permitted to make vows, even with "Harei Alu."

Perhaps in such a case there is no concern that it might lead to a stumbling block, as they will certainly fulfill their vow. This is what the verse means when it states, "Your heart shall not be grieved when you give to him." Rather, if your intention is proper, then "because of this matter, Hashem your G-d will bless you" - that you will receive reward even for the speech itself.

From this, there is support for the common practice at gatherings for supporting Torah institutions and yeshivos, where people announce and promise sums of money for tzedakah, even though not everyone has the means to pay immediately and say "Harei Zu." Nevertheless, with proper intention, the speech itself becomes a separate mitzvah, and one receives reward both for the declaration and the action.

However, each person should take to heart that they have a great responsibility to fulfill their vow, as this is our entire existence. We have no portion or inheritance in financial support that comes from impure sources, which are mainly given to unstable and corrupted institutions. I don't want to touch them as they are dangerous, Heaven forbid, to the spiritual nature of those who receive them.

The main foundation for maintaining our institutions comes only from those who fear Hashem, who are few. Although it is very difficult and comes with great toil and effort, one must gather strength with mesiras nefesh (self-sacrifice) to establish the yoke of Torah and support Torah institutions that are built on pure holiness, as this is the foundation of Judaism and the foundation for the continuation of future generations.

One can explain by first considering what our Sages taught (Berachos 5a): A person should always incite the yetzer tov (good inclination) against the yetzer hara (evil inclination), as it is said "Tremble and sin not." If he overcomes it, good; if not, he should engage in Torah study, as it is said "Speak in your hearts, etc." If this doesn't help, he should recite Krias Shema, etc. If this doesn't help, he should remember the day of death.

The Iyun Yaakov (by the author of Shvus Yaakov) asks why go through all this - why not immediately suggest remembering the day of death, since its effectiveness is clear and certain? The commentators explain allegorically the verse "Behold now, I have grown old, I know not the day of my death" - Yitzchak Avinu said that despite his advanced age, he never needed to know or remember his day of death, because he knew how to overcome the yetzer hara through the power of Torah and Krias Shema, serving Hashem with joy. The words of the Midrash mentioned above (in the previous drush) can be explained: "And Judah approached him" - Rabbi Yehuda says it was an approach for war, Rabbi Nechemia says it was an approach for appeasement, etc., and the Rabbis say it was an approach for prayer - and all these are the words of the living G-d. All these aspects were included in his words.

As we explained regarding Joseph's words, besides their simple meaning, the inner meaning of the words contained hints to lofty and hidden matters. Similarly were Judah's words, as written in the holy sefer Noam Elimelech (in Parshat Vayishlach) on the verse "Thus shall you say to my master, to Esau: 'I have sojourned with Laban, etc.'"

He [the Noam Elimelech] questioned why Jacob needed to mention and call Esau "my master" when speaking to the angels in his house. Also, the letter "lamed" in "l'Esau" (to Esau) seems unnecessary - he should have said "adoni Esau" (my master Esau). Furthermore, regarding Rashi's explanation that "I have sojourned with Laban" means "I kept the 613 mitzvot," would this really find favor in Esau's eyes?

Rather, the matter is that when a tzaddik speaks with people, he is precise in his words, ensuring that his words are heard in their simple meaning by the person he's speaking with, while the main content he intends with those words is prayer and supplication before HaKadosh Baruch Hu. The intention is to hide his words of prayer within the conversation he has with the person, and he doesn't explicitly state his needed prayer in order that the prosecutor (satan) won't understand his intention and won't prosecute him.

This is what Jacob said to the angels: "Thus shall you say" - in this manner and with this intention you should say all your words - "to my master," meaning your intention should be to the Master of All, the Blessed Creator, while also having a simple meaning for Esau that would be pleasing to him. This is why it says "Thus says your servant Jacob: 'I have sojourned with Laban,'" which can be understood in two ways: as words of advocacy before Hashem that he kept the 613 mitzvot, and this merit should protect him from Esau, and also in its simple meaning as words of appeasement and submission to Esau, that he was merely a stranger and didn't become important or powerful, as Rashi explains.

Similarly can be explained Judah's words to Joseph when he said "Please, my master, let your servant speak a word in my master's ears." When he mentioned "my master," the inner content of his words was prayer and supplication before the Creator, speaking words toward Above, but he concealed and clothed in his words also the simple meaning that would be words of appeasement and harsh words to Joseph. This explains well what our Sages said in the Midrash that this approach was for appeasement and for war with Joseph according to the simple meaning, and an approach of prayer to the Creator as mentioned above.

This explains the words of the Midrash where Abba Kohen Bardela said, "Woe to us from the Day of Judgment," and he brought proof from Bilaam who was liable according to the law. However, the holy tribes [sons of Jacob] did not come to this situation through their own actions, rather it was a necessity decreed from Heaven. Therefore, they were not liable in judgment. This is what the Midrash means when it says, "Woe to us from the Day of Judgment," as there are sins for which a person is liable, Heaven forbid, according to the strict letter of the law (din), through indirect causation (dina d'garmi) and the like. The proof is from the holy tribes who could not withstand Joseph's rebuke. Therefore, both aspects are mentioned as they represent two distinct categories.
